title: 109_hr2485
content: The Act may be cited as the "DSHEA Full Implementation and Enforcement Act of 2005". Congress finds that over 158 million Americans use dietary supplements, with consumer spending reaching $17.1 billion in 2000. The FDA predicts continued growth in supplement use due to factors like aging populations and advances in science. The DSHEA was enacted in 1994 to regulate dietary supplements. DSHEA, enacted in 1994, regulates dietary supplements by ensuring truthful, non-misleading, and substantiated claims on labels. It sets manufacturing standards for potency, purity, and safety of ingredients. The FDA has updated its system for reporting adverse events related to dietary supplements. DSHEA provides authorities to remove unsafe supplements from the market and created the Office of Dietary Supplements for research and consumer information. The FDA has not effectively enforced DSHEA and requires more resources for implementation. The FDA has received additional funds beyond the President's budget to enforce DSHEA, totaling $9,700,000 in 2003. However, the FDA states that full implementation of DSHEA would require between $24,000,000 and $65,000,000 annually. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION AND APPROPRIATION OF RESOURCES. Authorization of appropriations for the Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994 and regulatory requirements under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act for fiscal years 2006 to 2010: $20,000,000 for 2006, $30,000,000 for 2007, $40,000,000 for 2008, $50,000,000 for 2009, and $65,000,000 for 2010. For fiscal years 2006 to 2010, $20,000,000 is authorized for regulatory requirements for dietary supplements under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. The Office of Dietary Supplements at the National Institutes of Health is allocated $30,000,000 for 2006 and additional funds for 2007 to 2010 for research and consumer information development. The Food and Drug Administration is mandated to use the allocated funds to regulate dietary supplements. SEC. 4. ANNUAL ACCOUNTABILITY REPORT ON THE REGULATION OF DIETARY SUPPLEMENTS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit an annual report to Congress on the implementation and enforcement of the Dietary Supplement Health and Education Act of 1994. The report includes details on funding and personnel dedicated to dietary supplement regulation and adverse event reporting systems within the Food and Drug Administration. The annual report to Congress includes details on funding and personnel dedicated to enforcement of dietary supplement labeling, good manufacturing practices inspections, and new ingredient reviews by the Food and Drug Administration. It also covers the number of inspections conducted and enforcement actions taken. The annual report to Congress includes information on enforcement actions by the Food and Drug Administration and the Department of Health and Human Services related to dietary supplements, including false claims, research activities supported by the Office of Dietary Supplements, and any recommendations for administrative or legislative actions. The annual report to Congress includes enforcement actions related to dietary supplements by the FDA and HHS, research activities by the Office of Dietary Supplements, and recommendations for regulatory actions.
